ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The WWF Operating Company, LLC facility maintains the highest level of commitment to ensuring the ongoing integrity and safety associated with the RMP-regulated process onsite, the ammonia refrigeration system.  A rigorous PSM/RMP standard is implemented that helps to guide various levels of plant personnel in the proper ways to manage each of the elements of the RMP program, including the written Emergency Action Plan.



The facility utilizes the services of a professional refrigeration contractor (on call 24/7) to operate and maintain the ammonia refrigeration equipment.  The system equipment is also inspected via a daily routine log sheet by the in-house utilities maintenance mechanics to ensure it is functioning properly and in good repair.  Any time abnormal conditions are observed, the refrigeration contractor is immediately notified for maintenance and/or repairs.



The facility has an emergency evacuation plan that includes emergency shelter-in-place protocols in the event of an ammonia leak.  Initial and refresher training, in addition to routine practice drills, are provided to all employees to ensure a safe and efficient evacuation is conducted.  If an ammonia leak or an alarm indicating an ammonia leak is observed by facility personnel, the decision to either shelter in place or to evacuate the building is made by management.  Professional emergency responders and the facility's professional refrigeration service firm are called to assist with responding to the ammonia leak.  WWF Operating Company, LLC employees are trained to not conduct offensive or defensive emergency response activities related to the ammonia refrigeration system.



The City of Industry facility recently coordinated an emergency exercise with local emergency response agencies including the LA County Fire Department and County HazMat Team to ensure all parties are mutually aware of roles and responsibilities during an

emergency.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The WWF Operating Company, LLC facility is located at 18275 Arenth Ave., in the City of Industry, California. The facility is approximately 0.66 miles north of Highway 60 and 4.1 miles west of Highway 57.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban with a mixture of primarily industrial and commercial zones.  The regulated substance onsite is anhydrous ammonia which has a maximum intended inventory of 24,486 pounds.   The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed-loop cycle with no planned or anticipated emissions of ammonia and is used for refrigeration associated with the production and cold storage of dairy products.



A mechanical refrigeration system is a closed system that cycles the refrigerant, ammonia, from liquid to gas and back again.  As the refrigerant absorbs large amounts of heat from the source, the refrigerant experiences a phase change from liquid to vapor.  On the high side of the system at the Condensers, the refrigerant releases latent heat as it condenses from a vapor back into a liquid.  These types of systems are referred to as having two sides: a low pressure or low side, where the refrigerant absorbs heat as it evaporates, and a high pressure or high side, where the refrigerant vapor releases heat as it is condensed back into a liquid.  The system utilizes the refrigerant as a vehicle to move heat from the temperature-sensitive zone to the atmosphere.  



The low side of the refrigeration system typically uses one or more evaporators and/or other heat exchangers (ex: chillers) to remove heat from the space or product to be cooled.  An evaporator contains a set of continuous coils through which the refrigerant flows.  As the refrigerant absorbs heat from the air / fluid surrounding the evaporator / chiller piping, the refrigerant boils, changing phase from liquid to vapor.  To increase the rate of heat transfer, evaporators use fans, and chillers use pumps to circulate

the air / liquid across the heat transfer surfaces.



The low and high sides of the refrigeration system are separated by the compressors and the expansion valve.  The compressors are the driving force of the system.  They pull refrigerant vapor from the evaporator (low side) at a rate that will maintain the evaporator pressure required for the desired operating temperature.  At the same time, they pressurize the ammonia vapor and discharge it to the condensers.  The ammonia compressors at the WWF Operating Company, LLC facility are screw type machines.



Expansion valves meter the flow of liquid refrigerant from the high side to the low side by causing a pressure drop across the valve.  These valves are located between the receiver (high side) and the evaporators / heat exchangers (low side).  These valves, coupled with the capacities of the compressor, can help regulate the pressure of the evaporator thereby creating the cooling capabilities of the system.  The high side of the refrigeration system consists of a condenser and a receiver.  Warm refrigerant vapor enters the condenser after it has been pressurized by the compressor.  Evaporative condensers typically use air and water to assist in the removal of heat from the warm high-pressure ammonia vapor as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser.  As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the ammonia vapor inside the pipes, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows by gravity into the receiver.  The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side.  It also serves to hold the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not in operation.  The system is also equipped with an Automatic Purger that removes non-condensibles, i.e. air, from the system.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The WWF Operating Company, LLC facility's ammonia refrigeration system has many safety design feature

s.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with three different regulations requiring ongoing documentation and implementation of risk management policies and procedures including the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations.  The facility also operates in accordance with corporate oversight in the form of a detailed RMP and PSM standard policy that defines and guides facility personnel to ensure the risks of operating the ammonia refrigeration system are minimized.



The facility has trained in-house personnel who conduct the visual walkthroughs of the ammonia system on a daily basis and can identify issues with the system.  The facility also maintains a contract with a professional refrigeration contractor to conduct preventative maintenance and any necessary repairs, which includes 24/7 response.



Several departments within the facility (Maintenance, Utilities, Environmental Health & Safety, Engineering, Management) as well as outside resources (Refrigeration Contractor Representative, and a Risk Management Consultant) comprise the facility's PSM/RMP Committee that meets on a routine basis (typically monthly) to ensure the appropriate and ongoing implementation of the various elements of the programs.  Discussions range from outstanding corrective action items, to planned design changes to the ammonia system, to changes in plant personnel, to reviewing evacuation drill results, etc.  Significant issues that may be identified are brought to plant leadership to ensure appropriate resources are allocated.



The ammonia refrigeration system and the design of the associated safety features was in accordance with contemporary codes and standards.  The PSM/RMP Committee also routinely reviews Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) to ensure that the facility is maintained, and appropriate plans / adjustments are made

based on evolving industry standards.



Some specific safety features at the facility include a water diffusion tank, ammonia leak detectors in the engine room and other areas where ammonia equipment is located, and automatic shutdown systems.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained in a central location at the plant including engine room and the adjacent glycol room where heat is removed from a secondary heat transfer medium (glycol) that is used for cooling in the manufacturing processes throughout the plant.  All ammonia pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that are piped to the water diffusion tank.  Each compressor is equipped with an array of safety switches that alarm and then can cause the machine to shut down if extreme conditions (temperature, pressure, or level) are sensed.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.  The release must have caused at least one of the following:

  - On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

  - Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



An investigation into the facility's accident history conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation (June 2018) revealed that there have been no significant ammonia releases over the past five years (June 2013 to June 2018) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release at the facility.



A minor ammonia leak occurred in February 2017 from a valve defect that resulted in an approximately 4 pounds of ammonia being released.  A detailed Incident Inv

estigation was conducted, and no injuries or off-site consequences were noted.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The WWF Operating Company, LLC facility has a written emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is authored and maintained by the Environmental Health & Safety Department.  Initial and refresher training on the EAP is provided for all employees, as well as guests, vendors, and contractors.  Since facility employees do not engage in emergency "response" activities, the focus is kept on properly identifying potential emergency scenarios and effectively initiating the emergency action plan.



The Emergency Action Plan includes names and contact information of both WWF Operating Company personnel (local and remote), as well as outside resources such as the Fire Department, the refrigeration contractor, the National Response Center, the California State Office of Emergency Services, and various contractors that might be of assistance depending on the type of emergency.  The Plan also defines the intended response for employees, who are designated to either evacuate to assembly areas outside, or to shelter-in-place (depending on the type and extent of the emergency).



Emergency drills are conducted at the plant to ensure that employees are aware of the emergency protocols, and that they are able to implement the policy effectively.  The facility also maintains a safety committee that reviews specific issues such as the functioning of notification alarms and/or radios, emergency exits being clear, etc.  The written EAP policy is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure changes are addressed including to personnel, phone numbers, facility policies, and/or regulatory requirements.  The facility maintains an ongoing relationship with the local Fire Department to ensure a smooth response in case it is needed.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Revalidation study, including a Hazard and Op

erability (HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, was conducted in June 2018.  The PHA study generated mitigation measures to enhance the design and operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  Additional studies are also conducted on the ammonia refrigeration system and the associated PSM/RMP policies that typically result in recommendations for safety and operability improvements including: the Five-Year Mechanical Integrity Inspection, the Three-Year Compliance Audit, Incident Investigations, and PSM/RMP Committee Meetings.  Team members of the PSM/RMP Committee routinely review and discuss the status of outstanding corrective action items with the objective of resolving and closing issues as possible.



The EHS Department also develops and implements safety polices including Hazard Communication, Ammonia Awareness, and Evacuation Plan training for all employees that are provided on an ongoing basis.  Additional training is planned for specific Utilities Mechanics who are assigned duties of daily inspections of ammonia equipment in the form of Ammonia Operations Training.  WWF Operating Company, LLC encourages employee involvement in the ongoing development and implementation of the PSM and RMP elements, and also seeks expert guidance from outside resources to ensure continual improvement.
